Serbetcioglu School of Chemical Engineering, University of Bath, Bath BA2 7AY, UK Received 17 July 1995; revised 11 October 1995; accepted 16 October 1995 Abstract In the search for catalysts to be utilized in a new generation of catalytic gas turbine combustors it is not unusual to hear of catalysts that appear to have worked well in a laboratory environment but do not do so when installed in a high pressure pilot-scale rig. The influence that interphase and intraphase transport limitations may have on the rate of catalytic combustion of methane in a monolith reactor (with a 1.1 mm cell size) is investigated at a Reynolds number, Re ~ 103 (with P = 2 bar) and at Re = 104 (with P = 15 bar), for bulk gas temperatures varying from 623-873 K and at a bulk methane mole fraction of 0.02. It is shown that it is not an easy task to evaluate chemical kinetic expressions at conditions which truly represent even the first stage (e.g., at gas temperatures from 623-973 K) in a catalytic gas turbine combustor, for as reaction rates become very fast, interphase and intraphase transport limitations also become significant, e.g., when comparing reaction rates evaluated at incorrectly assigned conditions, then even at a relatively low bulk fluid temperature = 773 K, errors may vary from ca. 35% to 80% for Re = 104 and 103, respectively. In a laboratory test environment, where experiments may be performed close to atmospheric conditions, it is also shown that it is easy to over-temperature and hence damage the catalyst, and draw false conclusions about the catalyst being too active, e.g., considering interphase resistances alone, at a bulk fluid temperature of 773 K and Re = 103 the catalyst is damaged, whereas at Re = 10a this would not have occurred. As catalyst surface temperature exceeds 800 K, intraphase diffusion may become significant and the effectiveness factor soon becomes very much less than one. Therefore, reactor scale-up should be based on calculations where the combined effects of interphase and intraphase transport processes are coupled with reactions; scale-up based on simple multipliers, e.g., those derived from residence time or gas * Corresponding author. Modelling is shown to have an important role in catalyst and system design; if applied correctly, system development costs may be reduced. Keywords: Combustion (catalytic); Heat transfer; Mass transfer; Kinetic experiment; Monolith reactor; Methane; Diffusion 1. Introduction When designing catalyst systems for catalytic combustion applications, the influence that mass and heat transfer may have on the overall rate of the reaction should be considered most carefully. In the development of catalysts for a catalytic gas turbine combustor, this aspect is particularly important if the catalytic section(s) consists of different catalysts designed to operate over specified temperature ranges. Kolaczkowski [1 ] describes in a review article the challenges faced in the development of system concepts and the dilemma facing the designers who ideally would like to have a highly active catalyst system that would operate over a wide power load range (and, hence, catalyst surface temperature) without becoming de-activated. However, designers appear to recognise that it is unlikely to be realized in practice. Therefore, a variety of different system concepts are being considered and in all of these knowledge of the temperature profile along the catalytic stages is important, if catalyst over-temperature (and hence damage) is to be avoided. Knowledge about temperature profiles may be acquired from experimental studies in reactors operating at realistic conditions or from theoretical modelling studies in which reactions and the transport processes of heat, mass and momentum transfer are modelled in the reactor. Experimental studies at elevated temperatures and pressures are extremely costly to perform, especially if done by a 'trial and error' approach. On the other hand, modelling studies can be substantially less costly to perform. However, the models need to be developed on sound principles and require reliable kinetic expressions, and physical and chemical parameters that describe the physical properties and the transport processes in the reactor. The acquisition of rate expressions describing catalytic rate data is important not only for modelling studies, but also in the development of new catalysts and in the recognition of parameters that may promote or inhibit the rate of reaction. The development of catalytic rate expressions for the combustion of methane is not an easy task, since the reaction is highly exothermic and relatively little is known about the reaction mechanisms. Trimm [2] states that "despite consider- able study of the generalities of catalytic combustion, much less is known about particular aspects of the process". In order to compare alternative catalyst formulations, catalyst developers perform screening trials where the perfor- mance of one catalyst is compared with another at a pre-determined set of S.T. Kolaczkowski, S. Serbetcioglu /Applied Catalysis A: General 138 (1996) 199-214 201 conditions which may vary between the suppliers. Where milder conditions than those to be used in the actual reactor are employed, or the processes of heat, mass and momentum transfer are not representative, then false conclusions may be drawn about the need for improvement to the developed catalyst and how it may perform at actual operating conditions. In a review article, Rajadhyaksha and Doraiswamy [3] illustrate how kinetic parameters may be falsified by transport limitations which arise as elevated temperatures. Although it may therefore appear prudent to select low temperatures for kinetic studies, Carberry [4] warns of the dangers of assuming that a form of rate expression evaluated over a specified temperature and pressure range (which rests upon the assump- tion that only one step in a series of supposed elementary events is the rate determining step) is valid at different temperatures and pressures outside the ranges tested. Hayes and Kolaczkowski [5] show for laminar flow conditions in a monolith reactor and a f'n'st order reaction, how a dimensionless catalytic reaction number may be used to evaluate whether or not the rate is mass transfer controlled. They also show the danger of assuming that the reaction is mass transfer controlled and therefore also of assuming that the mole fraction of fuel at the wall is zero in order to back-calculate mass transfer coefficients under reaction conditions. In small diameter channels (ca. 1 mm), it is more difficult to become completely mass transfer controlled. Whereas in a large diameter channel (ca. 15 mm) at a laminar flow condition, Kolaczkowski et al. [6] have shown for the catalytic combustion of polychlorinated biphenyls that the reaction soon becomes mass transfer limited. In studies on the oxidation of carbon monoxide in a 15 mm internal diameter catalyst coated tube wall reactor, Hayes et al. [7] illustrate how entrance effects may enhance mass transfer and that both interphase and intraphase resistances are important. Unfortunately, studies on the relative influence of interphase and intraphase resistances at flow conditions representative of a gas turbine are scarce. Even when experimental results are reported on pilot-scale trials, catalyst durability and overall performance are the issues where emphasis has been placed. To illustrate the relative importance of heat and mass transfer, the catalytic combus- tion of methane at a local position in a multichannel monolith reactor is examined in this paper. This should help catalyst developers become more aware of the consequences of performing kinetic studies at relatively mild conditions and subsequent problems of scale-up. The operating conditions selected for this study may be considered to represent possible values for the first catalyst stage in a catalytic gas turbine combustor, in a scheme where catalytic combustion reactions are being maximised -- for examples see Ref. [1]. The possibility of homogeneous reactions is not considered in this paper; however, if bulk gas or even wall temperatures exceed 800, then these could very well be initiated in an actual application. 202 S.T. In order to give an indication of the possibly severity of this effect, for a 1.1 mm hydraulic diameter monolith channel, mass transfer coefficients were calculated for two different values of the Reynolds number, Re. This number is a dimensionless group which indicates whether the flow in the channel is laminar, transitional or turbulent. One of the values is in the laminar flow region, i.e., Re = 103, and the other is in the turbulent flow region, i.e., Re = 104. The laminar flow region could be considered to be representative of a laboratory reactor or a pilot-scale reactor, where gas flowrates are limited and so too are the operating pressures which are close to atmospheric. In the turbulent flow region, with Re = 104 and P = 15 bar, conditions are more representative of a gas turbine operating at medium/full power -- conditions at which the catalyst tested in the laboratory may need to perform. The design and construc- tion of apparatus to operate at 1073 K, 15-10 bar pressure and mass flowrates representative of a gas turbine is a costly exercise; it is therefore not surprising that experiments are performed at milder conditions. However, as shown in the illustrative calculations in this paper, transport limitations must not be neglected when interpreting kinetic rate data or when performing 'scale-up' calculations. This aspect is not always appreciated fully by catalyst developers. From Table 1, it is clearly evident that the coupled effects of both heat and mass transfer can have a significant effect on the overall rate of reaction in the monolith and cannot be neglected either in scale-up or kinetic studies. However, since intraphase resistance in the washcoat has not been considered, calculated values of reaction rates at the higher temperatures may be substantially different. 2.3. Intraphase mass and heat transfer Before the methane and oxygen can react on the catalytic sites, they must diffuse into the porous structure of the catalyst. This process is commonly known as intraphase diffusion and its influence on the overall reaction rate may be described in terms of the catalyst effectiveness factor which may be defined as: reaction rate affected by intraphase diffusion r/= (14) reaction rate unaffected by intraphase diffusion A value of r/= 1 would indicate that intraphase diffusion was not a significant limitation, whereas values of "0 < 1, e.g., r/-- 0.5, would indicate that only 50% of the catalyst was being utilized in an effective manner. It is therefore important to know how the effectiveness factor of the catalyst system may vary at reaction conditions (i.e., temperature, pressure and gas composition) represen- tative of the position in the catalytic combustor where the assessment needs to be made. If the performance of the catalyst is only being assessed at mild conditions, it is easy to jump to false conclusions, for example, that improve- ments to the catalyst formulation need to be made. These may subsequently prove not to be beneficial at actual operating conditions as intraphase diffusion limitations may be the problem and these had not been identified in the preliminary experiments. There are a number of ways in which the effectiveness factor of the catalyst may be quantified. For example, the equations describing the processes of intraphase diffusion and reaction(s) in the catalyst washcoat may be solved. Hayes and Kolaczkowski [5] report on the results of such calculations using a two-dimensional form of analysis. For the washcoat distribution in Fig. 4a, they assumed the distribution was symmetrical and therefore only needed to consider one octant of the cross-section. To simplify the calculation a one-dimensional form of analysis may be employed [ 11 ], by assuming that the distribution of the catalyst and washcoat is uniform around the perimeter of the cell -- the catalyst layer may then be modelled as a slab of thickness Lc, see Fig. 4b. It should by now be clear that intraphase diffusion may be a very important factor and one that cannot be ignored in any scale-up of data either from laboratory or pilot-scale studies. In reality, as the reaction proceeds in the catalyst layer, energy is released and transported to the surface of the coating. A temperature gradient therefore exists in the washcoat layer. Conclusions From this study, the following conclusions are of particular importance to designers of catalyst systems: 1. Because catalytic combustion reactions are extremely fast, both interphase and intraphase transport limitations are likely to be significant even in the first catalyst stage in a gas turbine combustor, where wall temperatures may vary from 623-1073 K. 212 S.T. Kolaczkowski, S. Serbetcioglu /Applied Catalysis A: General 138 (1996) 199-214 2. In laboratory chemical kinetic studies, if attempts are being made to perform experiments at temperatures likely to be encountered in the actual catalytic combustor, it may be very difficult to eliminate the effects of interphase and intraphase transport limitations. Where compromises are made and experi- ments are performed at lower temperatures and even pressures, there is the risk that the extrapolation of the rate expression to higher temperatures and pressures may cause significant errors. 3. Unless the combined effects of interphase and intraphase resistances with reactions are considered, substantial errors of judgement may be made about: 3.1. the suitability of a catalyst for the planned application, and 3.2. the ability of the catalyst system to perform at conditions that are different from those actually tested in the laboratory. It is possible that a good catalyst could be rejected, or unnecessary improvements sought in its formulation. Great care must be taken with scale-up and such calculations should be based on a model that com- bines the transport processes with reactions. Attempts to scale-up the results of atmospheric pressure experiments to elevated pressures and higher Reynolds numbers, utilizing simple approaches, e.g., based on residence time or gas hourly space velocity, are very naive and likely to result in substantial errors. 4. To avoid problems of scale-up, system designers may choose to perform experiments at actual test conditions; from the literature it is evident that some have followed this approach. However, high pressure pilot-scale experi- mental trials are an extremely costly method of screening catalysts and it may take a long time to find the right combination on a 'trial and error' basis. As illustrated with simple examples in this paper, modelling has a very impor- tant role to play in system design and, if applied correctly, it should result in lower costs being incurred at the development phase. 4. In the search for catalysts to be utilized in a new generation of catalytic gas turbine combustors it is not unusual to hear of catalysts that appear to have worked well in a laboratory environment but do not do so when installed in a high pressure pilot-scale rig. The influence that interphase and intraphase transport limitations may have on the rate of catalytic combustion of methane in a monolith reactor (with a 1.1 mm cell size) is investigated at a Reynolds number, Re = 103 (with) P = 2bar) and at Re = 104 (with P = 15bar), for bulk gas temperatures varying from 623–873 K and at a bulk methane mole fraction of 0.02. It is shown that it is not an easy task to evaluate chemical kinetic expressions at conditions which truly represent even the first stage (e.g., at gas temperatures from 623–973 K) in a catalytic gas turbine combustor, for as reaction rates become very fast, interphase and intraphase transport limitations also become significant, e.g., when comparing reaction rates evaluated at incorrectly assigned conditions, then even at a relatively low bulk fluid temperature= 773K, errors may vary from ca. 35% to 80% for Re = 104and103, respectively. In a laboratory test environment, where experiments may be performed close to atmospheric conditions, it is also shown that it is easy to over-temperature and hence damage the catalyst, and draw false conclusions about the catalyst being too active, e.g., considering interphase resistances alone, at a bulk fluid temperature of 773 K and Re = 103 the catalyst is damaged, whereas at Re = 104 this would not have occurred. As catalyst surface temperature exceeds 800 K, intraphase diffusion may become significant and the effectiveness factor soon becomes very much less than one. Therefore, reactor scale-up should be based on calculations where the combined effects of interphase and intraphase transport processes are coupled with reactions; scale-up based on simple multipliers, e.g., those derived from residence time or gas hourly space velocity, are unlikely to work. Modelling is shown to have an important role in catalyst and system design; if applied correctly, system development costs may be reduced.
